cards.Front: Name the four core components of a comprehensive physical activity program.
cards.Back: Aerobic/endurance; resistance/strength; flexibility; balance/neuromotor.

cards.Front: Define aerobic exercise in one sentence.
cards.Back: Rhythmic, sustained use of large muscle groups that stresses the cardiorespiratory system.

cards.Front: Define resistance training in one sentence.
cards.Back: Muscle contractions against external resistance to improve strength, muscular endurance, and lean mass.

cards.Front: What does flexibility training target?
cards.Back: Joint-specific range of motion via muscle–tendon–ligament extensibility.

cards.Front: What does balance (neuromotor) training improve?
cards.Back: Static/dynamic postural control and tolerance to destabilizing stimuli.

cards.Front: List three hallmark benefits of aerobic training.
cards.Back: ↓ all-cause/CVD mortality; ↓ several cancers; ↑ sleep/quality of life.

cards.Front: List five benefits of resistance training.
cards.Back: ↓ injury; ↑ basal metabolic rate; ↓ fatigue; ↑ sleep; ↑ performance/strength; ↑ bone mineral density (early post-menopause); ↓ body fat; ↑ glucose tolerance/insulin action; ↓ low back pain; ↓ falls; ↑ mental health.

cards.Front: Give two evidence-supported benefits of flexibility training.
cards.Back: ↑ muscle length & joint ROM; aligns collagen during healing (especially when tissues are warmed).

cards.Front: Give two common balance drills used in clinic.
cards.Back: Single-leg stance; tandem or backward walking; wobble/foam surface drills.

cards.Front: Which component most directly improves VO₂max?
cards.Back: Aerobic (endurance) training.

cards.Front: Which component most directly improves bone mineral density?
cards.Back: Resistance training (and some impact/plyometric activities).

cards.Front: Which component has the most mixed evidence for preventing injury when done alone?
cards.Back: Flexibility training, in part because intensity/dose is hard to quantify.

cards.Front: Simple balance progression you can cue in clinic.
cards.Back: Wider → narrow stance → tandem → single-leg; then add eyes closed or unstable surfaces, or dual-tasking.

cards.Front: How do aerobic and resistance training typically affect HDL and LDL?
cards.Back: Small ↑ HDL; minimal ↓ LDL with either alone (larger lipid changes usually require diet).

cards.Front: What underpins muscle hypertrophy at the cellular level?
cards.Back: Periods where muscle protein synthesis exceeds breakdown (positive net protein balance) via adequate training stimulus and nutrition.

cards.Front: Cloze: Aerobic exercise uses {{_____}} in a {{_____}} manner.
cards.Back: large muscle groups; rhythmic, sustained

cards.Front: Cloze: Resistance training improves {{_____}}, {{_____}}, and {{_____}}.
cards.Back: strength; muscular endurance; lean mass

cards.Front: Cloze: Flexibility is {{_____}}.
cards.Back: joint-specific range of motion

cards.Front: Cloze: Balance training enhances {{_____}} under {{_____}} conditions.
cards.Back: postural control; static and dynamic

cards.Front: Cloze: Aerobic + resistance alone typically cause {{_____}} and {{_____}}.
cards.Back: small ↑ HDL; minimal ↓ LDL

cards.Front: Cloze: Muscle hypertrophy requires {{_____}}.
cards.Back: positive net protein balance (MPS > MPB)

cards.Front: Cloze: Flexibility training has {{_____}} for injury prevention due to {{_____}}.
cards.Back: mixed evidence; hard-to-quantify intensity

cards.Front: Cloze: Balance programs in older adults {{_____}}.
cards.Back: reduce falls and related injuries

cards.Front: Cloze: Flexibility sessions typically use {{_____}} per stretch, {{_____}} reps, about {{_____}} per muscle group.
cards.Back: 10–30 seconds; 2–4; ~60 seconds total

cards.Front: Cloze: Resistance training frequency—train {{_____}}.
cards.Back: all major muscle groups ≥2 days/week

cards.Front: Differentiate physical activity (PA) from exercise.
cards.Back: PA: any skeletal-muscle movement that raises energy expenditure above rest (occupational, transport, household, leisure). Exercise: a planned, structured, repetitive subset of PA performed to improve or maintain fitness.

cards.Front: Define sedentary behavior.
cards.Back: Any waking behavior ≤1.5 METs in a seated, reclined, or lying posture; has distinct determinants/effects and confers independent health risk.

cards.Front: Define “inactive” and “insufficiently active.”
cards.Back: Inactive: 0 min/week of MVPA. Insufficiently active: >0 but <150 min/week of MVPA.

cards.Front: Does meeting MVPA targets eliminate the harms of prolonged sitting?
cards.Back: No. Prolonged sedentary time independently increases morbidity and mortality; break up sitting even if you meet MVPA.

cards.Front: Clinic prescription to break up sitting.
cards.Back: Take a 5-minute movement break every 50–60 minutes of sitting (walk, stairs, light calisthenics).

cards.Front: Do health benefits require reaching 150 min/week?
cards.Back: No. Benefits begin below 150 min/week; the biggest relative gains occur when moving from very low to modest activity.

cards.Front: What MET-hour range captures most mortality benefit?
cards.Back: Roughly 10–20 MET·h/week, with diminishing returns at higher volumes.

cards.Front: Weekend-warrior pattern—what’s the bottom line?
cards.Back: Concentrating ≥150 min/week into 1–2 days lowers mortality vs sedentary; distributing across ≥3 days may reduce injury risk.

cards.Front: Two acute (single-bout) effects of physical activity.
cards.Back: Improved executive function and transient reductions in blood pressure; reduced state anxiety; improved sleep quality.

cards.Front: Two early training effects (days–weeks).
cards.Back: Improved insulin sensitivity/glycemic control and better sleep quality.

cards.Front: Three long-term effects of regular physical activity.
cards.Back: Lower all-cause/CVD mortality; reduced T2D risk; improved physical function across the lifespan.

cards.Front: Steps and health—what’s the practical message?
cards.Back: Use **steps/day** as a simple volume proxy: more is generally better with diminishing returns; there is **no magic 10,000**—focus on gradual increases from baseline.

cards.Front: Step intensity—what cadence suggests moderate effort?
cards.Back: About **100 steps/min** is a practical marker for moderate intensity for many adults (individual variation applies).

cards.Front: Older adults and steps—what to emphasize?
cards.Back: Emphasize consistent daily stepping and breaking up sitting; moderate step goals (e.g., gradual increases of 1,000–2,000 steps/day from baseline) are effective and safer than aggressive jumps.

cards.Front: How to progress step goals from a low baseline.
cards.Back: Add ~1,000–2,000 steps/day above baseline over several weeks; pair with hourly 5-minute movement breaks.

cards.Front: Cloze: **Sedentary behavior** is {{_____}} in a {{_____}} posture.
cards.Back: ≤1.5 METs; seated/reclined/lying

cards.Front: Cloze: Meeting MVPA targets {{_____}} offset risks from {{_____}}.
cards.Back: does not; prolonged sitting

cards.Front: Cloze: Take a {{_____}} movement break every {{_____}} minutes of sitting.
cards.Back: 5-minute; 50–60

cards.Front: Cloze: Largest relative mortality benefit around {{_____}} MET·h/week.
Cloze: ‘Weekend-warrior’ = activity in {{_____}} days; still {{_____}} vs being sedentary.
cards.Back: 1–2; beneficial

cards.Front: Cloze: Moderate-intensity walking cadence ≈ {{_____}} steps/min (rule-of-thumb).
Which special populations are explicitly included under Objective 3 (list at least six)?
cards.Back: Older adults; pregnancy/postpartum; children & adolescents; obesity; disability; cardiovascular disease; type 2 diabetes; cancer; stroke.

cards.Front: An independent 78-year-old reports slow gait and difficulty rising from a chair. What simple assessment predicts mobility/disability and improves with training?
cards.Back: The Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB: gait speed, balance, chair rise).

cards.Front: What *minimum* weekly structure should most adults ≥65 aim for (aerobic, resistance, balance, flexibility)?
cards.Back: 150 min/wk moderate (or 75 min/wk vigorous or combo) **as able**; resistance ≥2 days/wk; balance ≥3 days/wk; flexibility ≥2 days/wk; progress conservatively if deconditioned.

cards.Front: In older adults, which declines faster—strength or muscle mass—and which better predicts disability/mortality?
cards.Back: Strength declines 2–5× faster than mass; strength (muscle quality) better predicts disability and mortality.

cards.Front: Clinic ask: You have 30 seconds with an older adult who fell twice this year. What specific training emphasis and frequency should you prescribe to reduce fall risk?
cards.Back: Neuromotor/balance training ≥3 times/week (e.g., progressive stance, Tai Chi) alongside strength work.

cards.Front: Vignette: A 30-week pregnant patient (previously a recreational runner) asks whether she can continue jogging. What’s the weekly target and key cautions?
cards.Back: ~150 min/wk moderate, spread across the week; may continue vigorous training if already well-tolerated with clinician guidance; avoid supine work after 1st trimester and direct spinal loading; hydrate and avoid heat stress.

cards.Front: Exam-style: Name three **absolute contraindications** to exercise during pregnancy that would prompt deferral and medical management.
cards.Back: Examples: severe heart disease with intolerance; severe respiratory disease; uncontrolled/severe arrhythmia; placental abruption; vasa previa; active preterm labor; severe preeclampsia; cervical insufficiency; uncontrolled type 1 diabetes.

cards.Front: What **types of activities** should be avoided during pregnancy due to fall or abdominal-trauma risk?
cards.Back: Contact/collision sports; horseback riding; downhill skiing; soccer; basketball; other high-fall or abdominal-trauma risk activities.

cards.Front: Board-style: What is the **daily** physical activity dose for children and adolescents, and which elements must be included weekly?
cards.Back: ≥60 min/day total PA; include **vigorous** activity ≥3 days/wk and **muscle- and bone-strengthening** activities ≥3 days/wk.

cards.Front: A school consult asks: beyond fitness, which **health and cognitive** outcomes improve with regular PA in youth?
cards.Back: Better cardiorespiratory and muscular fitness, bone health, weight/adiposity and cardiometabolic risk; fewer depressive symptoms; cognitive/academic gains (notably ages 6–13).

cards.Front: Weight management OSCE: quote the **ACSM volumes** for weight **maintenance** and typical **loss** without diet.
cards.Back: >250 min/wk moderate PA often needed for maintenance; for loss: <150 min minimal change; >150 min modest (~2–3 kg); 225–420 min/wk yields ~5–7.5 kg. Diet + PA works best; PA is critical for long-term maintenance.

cards.Front: Your patient increased exercise by 3000 kcal/week but lost less weight than expected. What two concepts explain this and what should you protect?
cards.Back: Energy compensation (increased intake) and reduced NEAT; intentionally preserve NEAT (daily steps/standing/incidental movement).

cards.Front: Adaptation check: When counseling adults with **mobility-limiting disabilities**, what principles guide safe, effective PA programming?
cards.Back: Use adult targets as tolerated; if not feasible, be as active as possible. Screen for balance/asymmetry, ROM limits, spasticity, autonomic issues; tailor modes (arm ergometer, seated resistance, aquatic, assisted gait).

cards.Front: Population question: How does **active commuting** (walking/cycling) relate to ischemic heart disease risk compared with inactive commuting?
cards.Back: Associated with lower IHD risk (HR ≈0.89 vs inactive commuting).

cards.Front: Clinic pearl: What is the **minimum effective dose** of moderate-intensity activity to reduce **incident type 2 diabetes** risk, and which training mode lowers HbA1c **most**?
cards.Back: ~150 min/wk moderate lowers T2D risk; structured **combined aerobic + resistance** training generally reduces HbA1c more than either alone, with >150 min/wk giving larger reductions.

cards.Front: Oncology consult: Which cancers show the strongest **prevention** evidence with higher PA, and what is the typical **risk reduction** range?
cards.Back: Colon (~17–30% lower) and breast (~20–30% lower) show strong evidence with dose–response patterns.

cards.Front: Survivorship counseling: What are the **exercise benefits during/after cancer treatment**, and how safe are supervised programs?
cards.Back: Improved cardiorespiratory fitness, body composition, treatment symptoms, and quality of life; supervised programs report low adverse-event rates.

cards.Front: Breast cancer follow-up: How does **post-diagnosis physical activity** relate to recurrence and survival?
cards.Back: Greater activity is associated with lower recurrence and improved survival.

cards.Front: Stroke rehab OSCE: Write a concise **FITT** anchor for exercise after stroke (aerobic, resistance, balance).
cards.Back: Aerobic ≥3x/wk progressing to 20–40 min/session at moderate intensity as tolerated; resistance 2x/wk for major muscle groups; add balance/gait training; monitor BP/HR and neurologic safety.

cards.Front: Stroke outcomes: Over weeks to months, what **functional changes** should you expect from aerobic ± resistance/balance training?
cards.Back: Improved maximal walking speed and 6-minute walk distance; adding resistance + balance further improves gait speed and balance.

cards.Front: Vignette: A 67-year-old with CHF NYHA II asks if exercise ‘can replace meds.’ What’s the accurate counseling point on **exercise vs pharmacotherapy** across CVD conditions?
cards.Back: Exercise confers mortality/functional benefits comparable to some drugs for CHD secondary prevention and stroke rehab, but in heart failure medication often outperforms exercise alone—use exercise **with** optimal medical therapy.

cards.Front: Quick recall (cloze): Children/adolescents need {{_____}} min/day, with {{_____}} intensity and {{_____}}/{{_____}} strengthening ≥3 days/week.
cards.Back: 60; vigorous; muscle; bone.

cards.Front: Quick recall (cloze): Pregnancy—avoid {{_____}} after the {{_____}} trimester and avoid activities with high {{_____}} risk.
cards.Back: supine exercises; first; abdominal trauma/falls.

cards.Front: Quick recall (cloze): For weight maintenance often need {{_____}} min/wk; ~5–7.5 kg loss typically requires {{_____}}–{{_____}} min/wk + diet.
Quick recall (cloze): In elders, adding {{_____}} training ≥3x/wk reduces {{_____}} and related injuries.
cards.Back: balance; falls.

cards.Front: Quick recall (cloze): In T2D, {{_____}} training often reduces HbA1c more than aerobic or resistance alone.
cards.Back: combined (aerobic + resistance).

cards.Front: PAGA—translate ‘equivalent combination’ into MET-minutes for exam math.
cards.Back: ~500–1000 MET-min/week delivers substantial health benefits (e.g., 150 min at 3–6 METs).

cards.Front: PAGA nuance—how are **bouts** treated in the 2018 update and what about breaking up sitting?
cards.Back: Any bout length counts toward totals; interrupt prolonged sitting even if you meet MVPA targets.

cards.Front: Exam calc: 30 min at ~4 METs, 5 d/wk—what weekly MET-min is this and does it meet core PAGA?
cards.Back: 30×4×5 = **600 MET-min/week**, within the 500–1000 MET-min target → meets core PAGA.

cards.Front: PAGA brain health—name **four** outcomes and their time course.
cards.Back: Sleep (same-day after a bout), executive function (acute + chronic), anxiety/depression (weeks–months), cognition across lifespan (chronic).

cards.Front: PAGA adult core dose—state it in one line.
cards.Back: **150–300 min/wk moderate** or **75–150 min/wk vigorous**, or an equivalent combination; more yields additional benefits.

cards.Front: PAGA—muscle-strengthening for adults (minimum).
cards.Back: Train all major muscle groups **≥2 days/week**; tailor to ability/health status.

cards.Front: Older adults (≥65)—what extra beyond adult basics?
cards.Back: Add **balance/neuromotor** training ≥3×/wk; tailor intensity/progression and accommodate comorbidities/fall risk.

cards.Front: Youth guideline—daily and weekly specifics you must remember.
cards.Back: **≥60 min/day** total PA; include **vigorous** ≥3 d/wk and **muscle- & bone-strengthening** activities ≥3 d/wk.

cards.Front: Clinic OSCE: a one-sentence PAGA counseling line for a busy adult.
cards.Back: “Move most days, add two strength days, and remember even short bursts count—build toward ~150 minutes/week.”

cards.Front: PAGA economics—what’s the most cost-effective primary-care intervention type?
cards.Back: **Brief advice** (in-person/phone/mail) generally outperforms supervised classes on cost-effectiveness per QALY.

cards.Front: PAVS—what is it and why use it?
cards.Back: A 2-item vital sign (days/week × minutes/day of moderate-to-vigorous PA) yielding weekly minutes for stratification, counseling, and quality metrics.

cards.Front: PAVS—ask the **two questions** verbatim.
cards.Back: (1) Days/week doing moderate to strenuous activity that makes heart beat faster/breathing harder? (2) Minutes on those days?

cards.Front: PAVS categories—what three labels do you map to quickly?
cards.Back: **Inactive** (0), **Insufficiently active** (>0–<150), **Meets/exceeds** (≥150 min/wk).

cards.Front: PAVS pitfalls—two documentation errors and how to avoid them.
cards.Back: (1) Counting light activity as MVPA → verify with talk test/RPE. (2) Recording weekly minutes without days/week → always collect both items.

cards.Front: Vignette: PAVS=0 but patient says ‘active at work.’ Two quick clarifiers.
cards.Back: Use **talk test** (“can you talk but not sing?”) and ask about **sustained** ≥10-min periods with heavier breathing/warmth.

cards.Front: 6-Minute Walk Test—what it measures and the right way to interpret.
cards.Back: Submax **functional capacity**; compare **within-person** pre→post. Standardize route/time/instructions for reliability.

cards.Front: Functional testing battery—pair one **balance** and one **lower-body power** test usable in clinic.
cards.Back: Balance: tandem or single-leg stance. Power: 5× sit-to-stand time or timed chair rise.

cards.Front: Define **physical activity**, **exercise**, and **sedentary behavior** for Rx docs.
cards.Back: PA: skeletal-muscle movement raising EE above rest. Exercise: planned/structured/repetitive PA for fitness. Sedentary: ≤1.5 METs seated/reclined/lying.

cards.Front: Intensity translation—give **moderate**/**vigorous** by %HRmax and %HRR.
Talk test—how to set moderate vs vigorous without devices.
cards.Back: Moderate: can talk but not sing. Vigorous: only a few words without pausing for breath.

cards.Front: RPE mapping—what ranges align with moderate/vigorous?
cards.Back: RPE **12–13** ≈ moderate; **14–17** ≈ vigorous; pair with talk test to titrate.

cards.Front: Resistance terms—define strength, endurance, power, and muscle quality.
cards.Back: Strength: maximal force (≈1RM). Endurance: sustain repeated contractions/time. Power: force×velocity (work/time). Muscle quality: force per unit muscle (lower intramuscular fat better).

cards.Front: FITT—adult **aerobic** starter Rx in one line.
cards.Back: F 3–5 d/wk; I moderate→vigorous (talk test/HRR); T 20–60 min/session (bouts count); T rhythmic large-muscle activities.

cards.Front: FITT—adult **resistance** starter Rx.
cards.Back: F ≥2 d/wk; I light→moderate then progress; T 1–3×(8–12 reps) (10–15 for older/deconditioned); T multi-joint + single-joint covering all major groups.

cards.Front: FITT—**flexibility** starter Rx.
cards.Back: F 2–3 d/wk (ideally daily); I to tension not pain; T 10–30 s holds; 2–4 reps to ~60 s/muscle; T major muscle-tendon units.

cards.Front: FITT—**balance/neuromotor** starter Rx & progressions.
cards.Back: F ≥2–3 d/wk (≥3 for older adults); progress **base** (wide→tandem→single-leg), **sensory** (eyes closed), **surface** (foam), **dual-task**; T 10–20 min.

cards.Front: Balance progressions—list four levers to raise difficulty.
cards.Back: Base of support, sensory (vision), surface stability, cognitive dual-tasking; add perturbations.

cards.Front: Deconditioned older adult—first-month resistance microcycle.
cards.Back: Full body 2 d/wk; 6–8 exercises; 1–2 sets of 10–15 reps, RPE 4–6/10; emphasize squat/hinge/push/pull/carry; 48–72 h recovery.

cards.Front: Type 2 Diabetes—**FITT Aerobic** (what/how much/how hard/how often).
cards.Back: F 3–5 d/wk; I moderate (progress to some vigorous as tolerated); T 20–60 min/session (bouts count) + **post-meal** walks 5–10 min; T walk/cycle/swim/row.

cards.Front: Type 2 Diabetes—**FITT Resistance** starter.
cards.Back: F 2–3 non-consecutive d/wk; I light→moderate then progress when >12 reps easy; T 1–3 sets of 8–12 reps, 8–10 exercises; T machines/free weights/bands (multi-joint emphasis).

cards.Front: Type 2 Diabetes—safety & monitoring anchors.
cards.Back: Daily foot checks if neuropathy; proper footwear; avoid barefoot; inspect skin post-exercise; log glucose response; watch hypoglycemia if on insulin/SUs.

cards.Front: Hypertension—**FITT Aerobic** + measurement protocol.
cards.Back: F 5–7 d/wk; I moderate (RPE 11–13); T 30–60 min; T walk/cycle/swim. Measure BP pre/post; postpone vigorous if **SBP ≥180** or **DBP ≥110**; include long cool-down.

cards.Front: Hypertension—**FITT Resistance** & breathing.
cards.Back: F 2–3 d/wk; I light→moderate, avoid near-max early; T 1–3×(8–12 reps), 8–10 exercises; exhale on exertion, avoid Valsalva; longer rests.

cards.Front: CVD—red flags to stop a session immediately.
cards.Back: Chest pain/pressure, syncope, new neuro deficits, abnormal hemodynamics, marked dyspnea at low workloads, arrhythmia symptoms.

cards.Front: Cardiac rehab—**aerobic spine** of the program.
cards.Back: ~**3 supervised sessions/week** for ~**12 weeks** (≈**36** visits) + home walks; begin light→moderate (RPE 11–13) under monitoring; build toward ~30 min/session; add intervals later as cleared.

cards.Front: Cardiac rehab—**resistance return** & education pillars.
cards.Back: Post-clearance: 30–40% 1RM upper / 50–60% lower to start; 1–2×(10–15 reps), 8–10 exercises, 2–3 d/wk; avoid Valsalva. Education: risk factor control, meds adherence, symptom recognition, nutrition, stress mgmt.

cards.Front: Heart failure (stable)—quick FITT anchor.
cards.Back: Aerobic 3–5 d/wk, light→moderate (RPE 11–13), 20–40 min total; intervals common. Resistance 1–2×(10–15 reps) for 8–10 exercises, 2 d/wk. Monitor fluid/weight changes.

cards.Front: Obesity—**FITT Aerobic** for loss vs maintenance.
cards.Back: Loss: **225–420 min/wk** moderate (~5–7.5 kg typical). Maintenance: **>250 min/wk** (often 60–90 min/day). Prefer low-impact modes; intervals for tolerance.

cards.Front: Obesity—resistance & **NEAT** strategy.
cards.Back: Resistance 2–3 d/wk, 1–3×(8–12 reps), full-body to preserve muscle/function. Protect **NEAT** (steps/standing breaks) during caloric deficit to limit compensation.

cards.Front: Obesity—progression and behavior anchors.
cards.Back: Increase minutes first (≤10–20%/wk), then frequency, then intensity; pair with diet; monitor sleep/stress; add +1000–2000 steps/day over baseline.

cards.Front: Pregnancy (uncomplicated)—**FITT Aerobic** & key cautions.
cards.Back: Most days to **~150 min/wk** moderate (talk test); pre-preg vigorous may continue with guidance; avoid hot/humid stress; hydrate.

cards.Front: Pregnancy—resistance/flexibility & **absolute contraindications** (examples).
cards.Back: Resistance 2 d/wk light→moderate; avoid supine after 1st trimester and direct spinal loading/hip hinging; switch to machines/bands; flexibility gentle. Absolute CI examples: severe heart/respiratory disease, uncontrolled/severe arrhythmias, placental abruption, vasa previa, active preterm labor, severe preeclampsia, cervical insufficiency, uncontrolled T1D.

cards.Front: Older adults—**power & falls** toolkit (what and why).
cards.Back: Sit-to-stands, step-ups, loaded carries with intentful speed; progress stance, add eyes-closed/foam/dual-task; power declines earlier than strength and impacts function; reduces falls when paired with balance ≥3×/wk.

cards.Front: Stroke (subacute/chronic)—FITT aerobic/balance & precautions.
cards.Back: Aerobic ≥3 d/wk, 20–40 min at RPE 11–13; task-specific gait practice; intervals as tolerated. Balance/gait 3+ d/wk with progressive challenges; monitor BP/HR and neurologic symptoms.

cards.Front: Stroke—resistance programming tweaks for spasticity.
cards.Back: 2 d/wk, 1–3×(10–15 reps); emphasize proximal stability, slow eccentrics, longer rests; avoid provoking spasticity; prioritize safe ROM.

cards.Front: Cancer (during/after tx)—FITT and special precautions.
cards.Back: Aerobic 3–5 d/wk, moderate→vigorous as tolerated; Resistance 2–3 d/wk, 1–3×(8–12 reps). **Bone mets**: avoid heavy/high-impact at involved sites; **Lymphedema**: start light, gradual progress, compression when indicated; supervised programs show low adverse-event rates.

cards.Front: Children & adolescents—weekly programming examples you can hand to schools.
cards.Back: Vigorous: relays, small-sided games; Muscle: body-weight circuits (push/pull/squat), climbing; Bone: hops/jumps/bounding with coaching and progression.

cards.Front: Universal progression—golden rules for novices/complex patients.
cards.Back: Change **one variable at a time**; weekly volume increases ≤**10–20%**; prioritize technique before load; plan longer cool-downs for older adults/meds.

cards.Front: Active commuting & IHD—what’s the association?
cards.Back: Walking/cycling to commute associates with **lower ischemic heart disease risk** (HR ≈0.89) vs inactive commuting.

cards.Front: Combined training—why is it superior for cardiometabolic risk (CVD + T2D)?
cards.Back: Aerobic improves cardiorespiratory fitness/insulin sensitivity; resistance improves glucose disposal, BP, muscle mass, function—together address multiple risk pathways.

cards.Front: Return-to-resistance—post-PCI/post-MI general difference (after clearance).
cards.Back: Uncomplicated **PCI** typically returns to light resistance sooner; **post-MI** timelines often longer; individualize per cardiology guidance and rehab progress.

cards.Front: Barriers & access—two reasons cardiac rehab is underutilized and a fix for each.
cards.Back: Referral gaps & travel/time burden. Fixes: automatic EHR referrals/enrollment; hybrid/home-based rehab models.

cards.Front: Universal Rx principle—what do you tell **every** patient regardless of condition?
cards.Back: “**Avoid inactivity.** Any movement helps; build toward **150–300 min/wk** moderate + **2 strength days**; if you can’t meet targets, do **as much as abilities allow**.”

cards.Front: Vignette—Obesity with knee OA: joint-friendly starter plan with progression and weight strategy.
cards.Back: Low-impact aerobic (cycle, pool/rower/elliptical) + resistance 2 d/wk; progress toward **250–300 min/wk** for maintenance/loss; pair with diet; protect **NEAT** to limit compensation.

cards.Front: Disability—autonomic dysfunction (SCI/MS): two monitoring tips.
cards.Back: Prefer **RPE** over HR alone; monitor temperature and orthostatic responses; allow longer cool-downs.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Pregnancy runner (30 weeks) wants to continue: best advice?
A) Stop now
B) Continue vigorous with no changes
C) Continue with clinician guidance; avoid supine after 1st trimester; manage heat/hydration
D) Resistance only
cards.Back: **C** — Continue with guidance; target ~150 min/wk moderate; may continue vigorous if previously tolerated; avoid supine after 1st trimester; manage heat/hydration.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Older adult with two falls: most impactful single addition?
A) Third resistance day
B) Balance/neuromotor ≥3×/wk
C) Daily static stretching
D) Vigorous intervals
cards.Back: **B** — Balance/neuromotor ≥3×/wk best reduces falls/injuries when layered onto aerobic/strength work.

cards.Front:
MCQ—T2D plan to lower HbA1c most effectively:
A) Aerobic only ≥150 min/wk
B) Resistance only ≥2 d/wk
C) **Combined aerobic + resistance** ≥150 min/wk
D) Any activity <60 min/wk
cards.Back: **C** — Combined training generally lowers HbA1c more than either alone at ≥150 min/wk.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Hypertension today SBP 184/DBP 112 at rest. Appropriate step?
A) Proceed with vigorous intervals
B) Begin moderate now and recheck after
C) **Postpone vigorous**, address BP; use long cool-downs when appropriate
D) Start heavy resistance
cards.Back: **C** — Postpone vigorous when **SBP ≥180** or **DBP ≥110**; optimize BP; gradual starts and long cool-downs.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Post-PCI (uncomplicated) at 1 week asks about lifting weights:
A) No lifting 6 months
B) **Light resistance under rehab supervision** after clearance; gradual progression; no Valsalva
C) Heavy bench press now
D) Aerobic only for life
cards.Back: **B** — Light resistance under supervision post-clearance with gradual progression; avoid Valsalva.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Bone metastases (femur) wants plyometrics. Best counsel:
A) Allowed if pain-free
B) **Avoid high-impact/heavy loads at involved sites**; choose low-impact/isometrics
C) Avoid any exercise
D) Upper-body plyometrics are fine
cards.Back: **B** — Avoid heavy/high-impact at affected regions; use low-impact/isometrics with supervision.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Stroke rehab early phase: safest initial intensity cue?
A) RPE 17–19
B) **RPE 11–13 with symptom monitoring**
C) HRmax >90%
D) ‘As hard as tolerable’
cards.Back: **B** — Start RPE 11–13 with close monitoring; progress as tolerated.

cards.Front:
MCQ—Weight-loss math doesn’t match the scale. Likeliest reason?
A) Muscle gain only
B) **Energy compensation and NEAT reductions**
C) Measurement error only
D) Water intake
cards.Back: **B** — Compensation and NEAT drop reduce net deficit; protect NEAT and sustain volume.

cards.Front:
MCQ—PAVS documentation error to avoid:
A) Calculating minutes/week from days×minutes
B) Asking about intensity explicitly
C) **Counting light activity as MVPA without verifying talk test**
D) Planning follow-up
cards.Back: **C** — Verify intensity with talk test/RPE before counting minutes as MVPA.

cards.Front:
MCQ—6MWT interpretation with greatest clinical value:
A) Single absolute distance vs norms
B) **Pre→post change within the same patient**
C) Compare to a friend
D) Different route/time of day
cards.Back: **B** — Use within-patient change; standardize testing.
